weekly_desc:
Okay, another week wrapped up. It's interesting to look back and see where the time actually went, especially when the schedule feels so packed.

This week felt... different. I definitely got a lot of sleep, which is great, and my stamina feels really high. I think that's largely thanks to all the time I spent at the Boathouse. Seriously, it felt like my second home this week. From early mornings to late evenings, I was there, either actively doing something or just hanging out. There were a few "activity" spikes there, which were probably some really intense practice sessions or maybe even a friendly competition. It's such a great way to stay active and clear my head, and I really enjoy the social aspect of it too. It definitely contributed to my social meter being at a decent level, even if it wasn't always traditional "socializing."

The flip side of that, though, is that my class attendance took a hit. Looking at my schedule, I pretty much missed all my classes this week – MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065. I know, I know. It wasn't intentional to skip them all, but one thing led to another, and the Boathouse just kept calling. I was in Sudikoff a few times, and even LSC, but not during my actual class times. It's a bit of a wake-up call, honestly. My knowledge meter is still at 50, but I know that's going to drop if I keep this up.

I did manage to get out a bit for some fun, like hitting up the Nugget Arcade on Sunday, which was a blast. And of course, the dining hall was a constant presence – gotta eat! But the academic side definitely needs some serious attention.

The biggest challenge staring me down right now is the sheer number of deadlines coming up. There are so many due on Friday, and then more on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday. It's a bit overwhelming when I haven't been in class to keep track of everything. I'm feeling pretty good physically, and my happiness is stable, but I can feel that little conscientious voice in my head getting louder about all the work I need to catch up on.

So, for next week, my goals are crystal clear:
1.  **Attend all my classes.** No excuses. I need to be in Kemeny, Sudikoff, and LSB when I'm supposed to be.
2.  **Prioritize academics.** I need to figure out what I missed, catch up on readings, and start chipping away at those assignments. I'll probably spend a lot more time in Sudikoff actually *doing* CS work.
3.  **Balance Boathouse time.** I love being there, but I need to make sure it doesn't completely derail my studies again. Maybe I can shift some of my Boathouse time to later in the day or consolidate it.
4.  **Proactively manage deadlines.** I'm going to map out all those upcoming due dates and create a solid plan to tackle them.

It was a week of high energy and good social vibes, but definitely a learning experience on the academic front. Time to get back on track!
judge_reasoning:
```

Missing all classes for a week significantly impacts knowledge acquisition, hence the drop from the initial 50.
- **Stress**: The student describes "the sheer number of deadlines coming up" as "a bit overwhelming" and notes that their "conscientious voice in my head getting louder about all the work I need to catch up on." This indicates a significant, rising level of academic stress.

- **Social**: The student mentions enjoying "the social aspect" of the Boathouse, which felt like their "second home," and that it "definitely contributed to my social meter being at a decent level, even if it wasn't always traditional 'socializing.'" They also refer to "good social vibes" from the week.

weekly_desc:
Okay, another week in the books! It feels like it flew by, honestly. Overall, I'm feeling pretty good – got a lot of energy, and my sleep has been fantastic, which is always a win. Socially, things are great too; I've been spending a ton of time with the team, which is always a blast.

This week was definitely a bit of a whirlwind, especially with all the early mornings and late nights down at the Boathouse. It feels like I practically live there sometimes! We've been really pushing hard with practices, and it's been incredibly rewarding. My stamina is through the roof, which is awesome, and I love the camaraderie. It's such a good group of people, and we really push each other.

Now, on the flip side, my class attendance this week was... well, it wasn't ideal. Looking at my schedule, I pretty much missed all my lectures for MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065. I know, I know, it's not great. It's tough when practices are so demanding and sometimes run right into or through class times. I did manage to get some work done in Sudikoff on Thursday and Friday afternoons, which was good for COSC, and I even pulled a late one there on Thursday night. And I was in the Life Sciences Center for a bit on Wednesday, so I wasn't *completely* off campus. But the actual lecture time? Yeah, that was a miss.

I can feel it in my knowledge levels, especially for some of the newer concepts. While my general understanding is still decent, there are definitely gaps forming in specific areas, probably from those missed COSC and Math lectures. It's a bit concerning, especially with so many deadlines piling up. I've got a whole bunch of assignments due across all my classes in the coming days and weeks, and I really need to get on top of them.

So, for next week, my main goal is to get back on track academically. I need to:
1.  **Prioritize class attendance:** I'm going to make a conscious effort to be in every lecture, even if it means adjusting my pre- or post-practice routine.
2.  **Catch up on missed material:** I'll dedicate specific blocks of time to review the lectures I missed this week, especially for MATH 023 and COSC 065. I'll hit up office hours if I need to.
3.  **Tackle those deadlines:** I'm going to map out all the upcoming assignments and start chipping away at them early. No more last-minute rushes!
4.  **Maintain the balance:** While academics are crucial, I also want to keep up with my athletic commitments and social life. It's all about finding that sweet spot where I can excel in everything without burning out.

I'm feeling optimistic about next week. I know I can get caught up, and I'm ready to put in the work. It's just about being more intentional with my time.
judge_reasoning:
```

weekly_desc:
Alright, another week in the books! It feels like time is just flying by, but in a good way.

This week was definitely a whirlwind, mostly centered around the Boathouse, which has pretty much become my second home. I spent so much time there – early mornings, late nights, even some afternoons. It's been incredible. The energy, the camaraderie with the team, pushing ourselves on the water – it's just such a great feeling. My stamina feels through the roof, and I've been sleeping like a log, which is amazing. Seriously, 100% sleep? I'll take it! And being around everyone, whether it's at the Boathouse or just grabbing meals at the Commons, has kept my social battery fully charged. I feel really happy and connected right now, which is awesome.

Now, on the flip side, I have to be honest with myself: my class attendance this week was... well, non-existent. The system even flagged "no class experience recorded," and yeah, that's pretty accurate. Between the Boathouse commitments and just getting caught up in other things, I completely missed all my scheduled classes for MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065. I know, I know. It's not ideal, especially with all those deadlines looming. Looking at the list, there are so many things due Friday, Monday, Thursday... it's a bit daunting when I haven't been in the lectures. My knowledge stats are a bit of a mixed bag, and I can definitely feel that gap growing in my course material.

It's a challenge, for sure, balancing everything I want to do with what I *need* to do. I love being active and social, and that's been fantastic for my overall well-being. But I also know that academics are why I'm here.

So, for next week, my main goal is to get back on track with classes. I need to make sure I'm actually *in* Kemeny, Sudikoff, and LSB during my scheduled times. I'll probably need to dedicate some serious time to catching up on the material I missed this week, especially with those deadlines staring me down. I'm going to map out my study plan for each course and make sure I allocate enough time to tackle those assignments. I want to keep up the positive energy and social connections, but I also need to prove to myself that I can manage both the academic rigor and my extracurricular passions. It's all about finding that sweet spot. I'm feeling good, so I'm confident I can make it happen!

weekly_desc:
This past week felt like a whirlwind, but in the best possible way. My energy levels are through the roof, and I'm feeling incredibly happy and connected, which is always a great place to be.

Looking back, it's pretty clear where most of my time and focus went: the Boathouse. Seriously, it felt like my second home this week, and sometimes even my first! There were so many early mornings and late nights there, especially Thursday, Friday, Monday, and Tuesday. It was intense, but honestly, I wouldn't trade those moments for anything. The team dynamic is just incredible, and pushing ourselves like that, even at 1 AM or 3 AM, really builds something special. It's probably why my stamina and sleep stats are so high – I'm getting good rest when I do sleep, and the activity keeps me feeling strong.

However, this intense focus on the Boathouse did come with a significant trade-off. I noticed that I didn't make it to any of my scheduled classes this week. My schedule had MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065, but during those times, I was either at the Commons, the Boathouse, or even back in my dorm. It's a bit of a wake-up call, especially with so many deadlines looming. I've got a ton of assignments due across all my courses – practically every day next week has something, from Friday to Tuesday. My knowledge stats are a bit concerning, and I know missing lectures isn't helping that. It's a challenge to balance this deep commitment to the team with my academic responsibilities.

On the social front, things are fantastic. Spending so much time at the Commons for meals, and the general camaraderie around campus, has kept my social battery fully charged. I also managed to squeeze in a good workout at the Alumni Gym on Saturday, which felt great. Even the random stops at Tuck School of Business or the Admissions Office felt like interesting diversions, though I'm not entirely sure what I was doing there at the time!

Overall, I'm feeling really positive. The high happiness and social connection are definitely highlights. The main challenge is definitely the academic catch-up.

For next week, my goals are pretty clear:
1.  **Prioritize Class Attendance:** I absolutely need to be in Kemeny, Sudikoff, and LSB for my classes. I need to figure out how to manage my time better around the Boathouse schedule to ensure I'm there.
2.  **Academic Catch-Up:** I'll dedicate specific blocks of time to review the material I missed in MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065. I'll probably hit up Fairchild Physical Sciences Center for some focused study time.
3.  **Tackle Deadlines:** With so many assignments due, I need to get a head start. I'll map out all the deadlines and break down the work into manageable chunks.
4.  **Maintain Balance:** I want to keep up the physical activity and social connections that make me feel so good, but find a more sustainable way to integrate them with my studies. It's about finding that sweet spot where I can excel in all areas.

It's going to be a busy week, but I'm ready for it. I'm confident I can get back on track academically while still enjoying everything else campus life has to offer.

This week was a bit of a whirlwind, mostly centered around the boathouse. Seriously, those early morning practices are no joke, but there's something so incredibly satisfying about being out on the water as the sun comes up. I was there pretty much every morning, and then again for some afternoon sessions too. It's demanding, but I feel so strong and focused after each one. It's definitely where a lot of my stamina is going, but it's also where I feel most alive. I even squeezed in some time at the gym, which was good for a change of pace.

Because of the intense boathouse schedule, I have to admit, my formal class attendance wasn't exactly stellar this week. I didn't make it to my scheduled MATH 023, COSC 069, or COSC 065 classes. I know I need to be more proactive about catching up on the material. My knowledge level feels okay, but there's always room to grow, especially when you're not in the lecture hall.

Speaking of academics, looking at the sheer number of deadlines coming up is a bit daunting, but I'm not panicking. There are so many due dates piling up for Friday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday – it's a constant stream! It just means I need to be super organized and disciplined with my time next week. I'm already thinking about how to structure my study sessions around my boathouse commitments.

Socially, things have been fantastic. I've been grabbing meals at the Commons, even if I'm not always "active" there according to my tracker – I'm definitely chatting and laughing with friends. It's been great to just hang out and decompress. I even found myself around the Admissions Office a couple of times, which was interesting.

My main challenge, as always, is finding that perfect balance between my passion for rowing and keeping up with my coursework. It's a constant juggle, but I'm confident I can handle it.

For next week, my goals are pretty clear:
1.  **Prioritize academics:** I need to make a concerted effort to attend all my scheduled classes – MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065. No excuses.
2.  **Tackle deadlines early:** With so many assignments due, I want to get a head start on them, especially the ones for Friday and Monday. I'll break them down into smaller, manageable chunks.

Overall, it was a really positive week. I feel healthy, happy, and connected. Just need to dial in the academic focus a bit more for the coming days!

Now, on the academic front… I have to be honest, my class attendance wasn't exactly stellar this week. Looking back, it seems I only made it to COSC 069 on Tuesday. Speaking of challenges, the sheer number of deadlines coming up is a bit daunting, especially since I haven't been as on top of things as I usually like to be. My conscientiousness is definitely kicking in now, telling me it's time to get serious.

What a week! It feels like it just flew by, and honestly, I'm feeling pretty fantastic overall. My energy levels are through the roof, I've been sleeping really well, and my social battery is definitely fully charged. It's been awesome connecting with so many people and just being out and about.

I spent a ton of time at the Commons this week, just hanging out and catching up with friends over meals. It's such a lively spot, and I love soaking in the campus atmosphere. And the Boathouse! I practically lived there. Between practices and just chilling by the water, it's become such a central part of my routine. I even managed to squeeze in some time volunteering at the Admissions Office, which is always rewarding. It's cool to share my experiences here with prospective students.

Now, for the academic side of things… this is where I need to be really honest with myself. Looking back, I definitely got a bit *too* caught up in everything else. My schedule says I had classes, but my actual attendance record tells a different story. I think I only made it to COSC 069 on Tuesday, which was good – it was in Sudikoff, and it felt productive to finally be there. But for Math and COSC 065, I just… didn't make it. I was either at the Commons, the Boathouse, or somewhere else entirely. It’s not like me to miss so much, and I know I need to be more disciplined.

My knowledge score is definitely reflecting that lack of classroom time, and that’s a bit of a wake-up call. I’m usually so on top of things, but this week, the social and extracurricular pull was just really strong. It’s a good problem to have, I guess – being happy and engaged – but not at the expense of my studies.

The upcoming deadlines are staring me down, and there are quite a few of them across the next week or so. That’s a clear sign I need to shift gears.

So, for next week, my goals are pretty clear:
1.  **Prioritize Class Attendance:** No more excuses. I need to be in Kemeny for Math and LSB for COSC 065, and obviously back in Sudikoff for COSC 069. I'll set extra alarms and make sure I'm heading straight there.
2.  **Dedicated Study Time:** I need to block out specific chunks of time each day for focused work, especially for the material I missed. I'll probably head to Sudikoff or the library to really buckle down.
3.  **Proactive Deadline Management:** With so many deadlines coming up, I need to map them all out and start chipping away at them early. No last-minute rushes!
4.  **Balance:** While I love being social and active, I need to find a better balance. Maybe fewer long hangouts at the Commons during prime study hours, or scheduling my Boathouse time more strategically.

I’m feeling really positive about turning this around. I know I can do it, and I’m excited to get back on track academically while still enjoying everything else campus has to offer. It’s all about finding that sweet spot.

weekly_desc:
Okay, journal time. This week felt… interesting. On the one hand, I'm feeling fantastic! My energy levels are through the roof, I've been sleeping like a log, and my social battery is absolutely buzzing. Seriously, I feel so connected with everyone, and it's been great just being out and about. My stamina is super high too, which is always a plus.

Now, for the academic side of things. This week was a bit… unconventional, I guess you could say. Looking back, I didn't actually make it to any of my scheduled classes – MATH 023, COSC 069, or COSC 065. It's not like me to miss lectures, especially with how organized I usually am. I think I just got really caught up in the flow of things, you know? There was so much going on socially, and I found myself spending a lot of time at the Class of 1953 Commons, just hanging out and grabbing meals with friends. It's such a vibrant spot, and it's easy to lose track of time when you're having good conversations.

I also spent a significant amount of time down at the Dartmouth College Boathouse. I love being by the water, and it's a great place to clear my head or just enjoy the atmosphere. I even popped into The Works Café on Thursday afternoon, which was a nice change of scenery. It was a good spot to just chill for a bit. I guess I was prioritizing a lot of the real-world connections and experiences this week.

My knowledge level is sitting at 65, which isn't terrible, but it's definitely something I need to focus on improving, especially after missing classes. I know I can catch up on the material, and I'm already thinking about how to structure my time more effectively next week.

Speaking of which, the sheer number of upcoming deadlines is a bit daunting, but I'm not stressed about it. I've got a plan forming in my head. There are so many due dates scattered across Friday, Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, and Thursday – it's a full calendar!

**Challenges this week:** Definitely the class attendance. It's a bit of a wake-up call. While I loved the social aspect and feeling so connected, I need to make sure I'm balancing that with my academic responsibilities. It's not that I wasn't engaged with learning, but the formal structure of lectures just didn't happen for me this week.

**Goals for next week:**
1.  **Get back into the classroom routine:** I need to make sure I'm physically present for all my lectures. I learn best when I'm there, engaging with the professors and my peers.

weekly_desc:
Wow, another week just flew by! Honestly, I'm feeling really good right now. My energy levels are high, I'm sleeping well, and I've been able to connect with friends, which always boosts my mood. It feels like I'm in a really good rhythm, which is super helpful with everything going on.

Academically, it was a solid week. I was in all my classes – MATH 023, COSC 069, and COSC 065 – and while nothing particularly dramatic or standout happened, I felt really engaged. In MATH, we're starting to get into some pretty complex topics, and I'm really trying to dig deep and understand the underlying principles, not just memorize formulas. It's challenging, but in a good way – it makes me want to explore different ways of thinking about the problems. COSC 069 is always a blast, and I enjoyed the discussions we had, even if it felt like we were just building foundational knowledge. And COSC 065 is definitely pushing me to think differently, which I appreciate. I know my knowledge scores are still relatively low, but that just means there's so much more to learn, and I'm genuinely excited about that.

Campus life felt vibrant, as usual. I spent a good amount of time in Kemeny and Sudikoff for classes, and LSB too. It's always nice to walk around and just soak in the atmosphere. I made sure to take some breaks and just enjoy being outside when I could.

Socially, it was a great week too. I made sure to carve out time to hang out with friends, whether it was grabbing a meal or just chatting between classes. It’s so important to have those connections, and I really value the people around me. We even managed to get some group study time in for COSC, which was productive and fun. It’s always easier to tackle tough problems when you’re bouncing ideas off each other.

As for challenges, I wouldn't say there were any major roadblocks this week, which is a relief. The biggest thing on my mind is definitely the sheer volume of upcoming deadlines. Looking at the list, it's a bit daunting – there are so many things due in the next couple of weeks across all my courses. It’s not stressful in a bad way, more like a big puzzle to organize and conquer. I want to make sure I'm not just completing assignments, but truly mastering the material.

So, for next week, my main goals are pretty clear:
1.  **Proactive Planning:** I need to sit down and map out all those deadlines. I want to break down each assignment into smaller, manageable chunks and schedule dedicated time for them. I'm thinking of using my planner even more rigorously.
2.  **Deep Dive into Concepts:** Especially for MATH and COSC 065, I want to spend extra time reviewing lecture notes and textbook chapters. I want to make sure I'm not just keeping up, but really understanding the 'why' behind everything. Maybe even try some extra practice problems beyond what's assigned.
3.  **Maintain Balance:** Even with the academic push, I want to make sure I continue prioritizing my sleep, social connections, and overall well-being. It’s easy to get caught up in the grind, but I know staying balanced is key to performing my best. I'll definitely keep those social meet-ups on the calendar!

Overall, feeling positive and ready to tackle whatever comes next. It’s going to be a busy few weeks, but I feel well-prepared and motivated.
judge_reasoning:
```

- **Stamina**: The student explicitly states, "My energy levels are high" and "I'm feeling really good right now," indicating excellent physical and mental energy. They also mention feeling "well-prepared and motivated" to tackle upcoming challenges.

They appreciate that COSC 065 is "pushing me to think differently." While acknowledging "my knowledge scores are still relatively low," they frame this positively as "so much more to learn, and I'm genuinely excited about that," indicating a strong growth mindset and engagement with learning.
- **Stress**: The student states, "I wouldn't say there were any major roadblocks this week, which is a relief." While they note "the sheer volume of upcoming deadlines" is "a bit daunting," they immediately qualify this by saying, "It’s not stressful in a bad way, more like a big puzzle to organize and conquer," demonstrating a positive and proactive approach to potential stressors.
- **Happy**: The student repeatedly expresses positive emotions, starting with "Honestly, I'm feeling really good right now." They mention connecting with friends "always boosts my mood," feeling "in a really good rhythm," and that COSC 069 is "always a blast." The overall sentiment is "feeling positive and ready to tackle whatever comes next."

- **Social**: The student describes a very positive social week, stating, "I've been able to connect with friends, which always boosts my mood" and "Socially, it was a great week too." They emphasize the importance of "those connections" and "value the people around me," actively carving out time for social interactions and even group study.

project.full_text_response:
This is an exceptionally well-articulated and thoughtful project idea. Your high conscientiousness is evident in the detailed breakdown, and your desire to connect people and solve a common problem shines through.

Here's my evaluation of "Dartmouth Brainwave" based on the criteria:

*   **Is the idea innovative or unique compared to existing apps?**
    While the broad concept of "finding study partners" isn't entirely new, your focus on *spontaneous, real-time, short-term, immediate help* is a significant differentiator. Many existing platforms facilitate scheduled study groups, but the "I need 15 minutes right now" aspect, especially with the potential for proximity-based matching, addresses a specific, often unmet need for instant academic micro-collaboration. It's a clever refinement of existing concepts, making it genuinely unique in its specific application.
*   **Does it clearly address a real problem or user need?**
    Absolutely. You've perfectly captured the common student dilemma of needing quick, targeted help without the overhead of organizing a full study session. The inefficiency of current methods is a pain point many students experience. This app directly addresses that friction, making academic support more accessible and immediate.
*   **Is the idea technically feasible for implementation by a student team within one semester?**
    Yes, highly feasible. You've clearly thought through the core technical components (UI/UX, authentication, real-time database, notifications, messaging) and correctly identified Firebase/Firestore as a suitable backend, which simplifies much of the server-side complexity for a student project. Your understanding of what constitutes a "strong bonus" (location services) versus core functionality demonstrates excellent scope awareness.
*   **Is the scope appropriate (not too simple, not too ambitious)?**
    The scope is near-perfect. It's robust enough to demonstrate a wide range of smartphone programming skills (real-time data, user interaction, notifications, potentially location services) without becoming overwhelming for a single semester. Your clear distinction between core features and future enhancements shows strong project management foresight.
*   **Does it demonstrate thoughtful consideration of user experience and impact?**
    Without a doubt. You've articulated the user's pain points, the desired user flow (quick posts, filtering, direct chat), and the positive impact on academic collaboration and community support. The features are designed with the user's immediate needs and convenience in mind, aiming to reduce friction and foster genuine connections. Your personal reflection on connecting people further reinforces this user-centric approach.

---

**29/30**

weekly_desc:
This week felt like a really good rhythm-setter, honestly. I'm feeling incredibly energized and just generally happy, which is a fantastic way to start or continue any week. My sleep has been great, and I've felt really strong and ready to tackle whatever comes my way. It’s been easy to stay on top of things when you’re feeling this well-rested and positive.

Academically, it was a week of consistent attendance and absorbing information. I was in Kemeny for MATH 023, then over to Sudikoff for COSC 069, and LSB for COSC 065 – it’s a good circuit. While I don't have any specific "aha!" moments or big breakthroughs to jot down from class this week, it felt more like a foundational period. We covered a lot of ground, and I was definitely engaged, taking notes and trying to connect the dots. Sometimes weeks are like that, less about a single memorable lecture and more about building a solid base. I'm really looking forward to seeing how these initial concepts build into more complex ideas. I feel like I'm steadily building up my understanding, even if it's not always in dramatic leaps.

The biggest thing on my mind, looking ahead, is the sheer number of deadlines piling up. It feels like every day next week has something due, especially towards the end of the week. It’s a bit daunting to see so many things on the horizon, but I’m trying to view it as a challenge to organize and prioritize effectively. It just means I need to be extra diligent with my time management and start chipping away at things early.

Outside of classes, I’ve had a really great time connecting with friends and just enjoying campus life. It’s so easy to find people to chat with or grab a meal with, and those social interactions really keep my spirits high. Balancing everything feels pretty natural right now, which is a huge relief.

For next week, my main goal is to really dive deep into the material for all my classes, especially with those deadlines looming. I want to make sure I’m not just attending, but truly mastering the concepts. I’ll be mapping out my study schedule to tackle each assignment systematically. And, of course, I want to keep up with these great habits – getting enough sleep, staying active, and making time for friends. It’s all about maintaining that balance and momentum. I'm ready for it!

They also mention that social interactions "really keep my spirits high" and that balancing everything feels like "a huge relief."
